title: What is CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)?
content: Explain what CSRF attacks are and how they work in web applications.
sampleAnswers: CSRF tricks a logged-in user into performing unwanted actions on a web application by submitting requests without their consent, using their authentication credentials.

title: Which measures can prevent CSRF attacks?

options.text: Validate the Origin and Referer headers
Require user confirmation for critical actions

explanation: CSRF prevention uses tokens, checks headers, and sometimes asks users for confirmation.

title: True or False: MITM attacks can steal data from HTTPS connections if SSL/TLS is not validated correctly.
content: Evaluate whether this statement is true or false.

options.explanation: Improper certificate validation or self-signed certs allow MITM attacks even over HTTPS.

title: What is the purpose of a Content Security Policy (CSP)?
content: Explain how CSP protects web applications and what types of attacks it mitigates.
sampleAnswers: CSP restricts which sources are allowed for scripts, styles, and media. It reduces XSS, clickjacking, and data injection risks.

title: Which of the following headers help improve web security?
explanation: HSTS, X-Content-Type-Options, and X-Frame-Options improve security; X-Powered-By reveals server info and is not protective.

title: True or False: Using HTTPS alone completely protects against XSS.

options.explanation: HTTPS protects data in transit but does not prevent script injection on the client side.

title: How can you prevent DOM-based XSS in JavaScript?
content: Explain best practices for preventing DOM-based XSS attacks in frontend code.
sampleAnswers: Avoid setting innerHTML with untrusted input, sanitize inputs with libraries like DOMPurify, use textContent instead of innerHTML, and avoid inline event handlers.

title: Which of these are valid ways to secure cookies against XSS and CSRF?
explanation: HttpOnly prevents JS access, Secure restricts to HTTPS, and SameSite limits cross-site requests. LocalStorage is accessible by JS and vulnerable to XSS.

title: True or False: Using third-party JavaScript libraries without review is safe if your site uses HTTPS.

options.explanation: Even over HTTPS, malicious or vulnerable third-party JS can introduce XSS or malware.
